On Apr 30, 2008, at 10:52 PM, Nick Gall wrote:
> Discussions about URI sch=
emas/templates, parametric URIs, URI  
> opaqueness go back a long way.I am=
 highlighting what I believe is a  
> critical issue that came up in my dis=
cussion with Andrew Townley. I  
> would really like feedback on this inter=
esting issue.
>
> The TAG finding on the use of metadata in URIs states tha=
t the use  
> of FORM in a returned HTML representation effectively "assert=
s" or  
> "assures" that the "assigning authority" is "supporting a class o=
f  
> parameterized URIs". This raises the following questions:
> 	=95 Do y=
ou agree?

Yes, sure. That is how clients bind to the objects they want to =
invoke  
methods on. This not only applies to forms but to anything the cli=
ent  
learns about the resources it comes across.
Statements made by the au=
thority of the resource take precedence over  
statements made by other aut=
horities, tough.

> 	=95 If so, then how long is such an assertion/assuranc=
e good for?

As long as the representation is said to be valid (IOW cacheab=
le).

> 	=95 For example, if I save an HTML page on my client, should the  =

> embedded FORM(s) work hours, days, weeks, months, years later?

See e.g.=
 the Expires header.

>
> 	=95 Since every use of any URI (parametric or no=
t) is an assertion or  
> assurance that the assigning authority will suppo=
rt the specific URI  
> for a long time -- at least if the authority is fol=
lowing the "cool  
> URI" practice -- why shouldn't the use of a FORM-based=
 parametric  
> URI also be an assertion or assurance that the assigning au=
thority  
> will support the specific FORM for a long time?
> 	=95 In other=
 words, should "cool FORMs" like cool URIs last a long  
> time?

No, not a=
t all. The important part of the hypermedia as the engine of  
app state is=
 that the server can *change* it without breaking client  
assumptions.

Th=
ere is a caveat to all this: by the time the client actually makes  
the re=
quest, there is no way for it to communicate any specific  
expectation it =
has (e.g. by submitting this form I want to order that  
book), it must rel=
y on the server being what it said before it is.  
Even if the client check=
s back right before the request, there still  
is a gap and the resource it=
 POSTs to could change dramatically.

The intended solution for this gap is=
 the Expect header which allows  
the client to tell the server what it exp=
ects and allow the server to  
report back if that expectation can no longe=
r e met. In practice  
Expect is not implemented as far as I know (IIRC the=
re is a reason in  
terms of architectural principles that it is not used, =
but I cannot  
remember it now).
